content: Hello everyone. Welcome to this self-paced session on statistics and probability in data
signs. In this session we will cover the basics of data and various types of data. So let's
go ahead and take a look at the agenda for this session. So we are going to start with
the introduction to data and then we will move on to various types of data. After a quick
difference between qualitative and quantitative data, we will cover the various types of data
such as discrete continuous, categorical and ordinal data with examples. I hope the
agenda is clear to you guys. So let's go ahead and start the session. Data is nothing but
any information that can be translated into useful information. The data can be collected
through various sources and accumulated in different formats. The analysis and statistical
methods are used to make sense of unstructured and structured data together useful actionable
insights for decision making in domains such as healthcare, policy making, sports, finance,
etc. And now that we have a slight area about what data is, let's go ahead and understand
the various types of data that is available to us. There are mainly two types or categories
of data. There are two types or categories of data that can be translated into information,
qualitative and quantitative data. So when we talk about qualitative data, it is the
kind of data where we cannot express the measure of the information in terms of numbers.
Qualitative data expresses the quality of certain features, for example, the data collected
through questionnaires, surveys and similar sources gives the qualitative perspective of
information like what is the qualification of a student, how many schools did one person
change during their educational life, etc. Moving on to quantitative data, this type of
data gives the exact information in terms of quantity. A simple example would be, what
was the revenue for the third quarter of a FinTech company, what was the average temperature
in the month of January for the city of New York, etc. To understand the difference between
the two, let's take a look at some of the key points that can help you differentiate
between qualitative and quantitative data. The very first distinguishing point is that
qualitative data will describe the quality of the information and the quantitative data
will describe the quantity. After that, we can distinguish between qualitative and quantitative
based on how the data is collected. In qualitative data, the information often is categorized
into various categories and for qualitative data, the information is gathered based on
numerical significance as discussed in the examples in the previous section. Another distinguishing
characteristic would be to just observe, let's say in an event, if the information gives
answers to why and how often event, it is qualitative in nature. As for quantitative data,
the event answers the information in terms of how many. The next difference is qualitative
data is subjective in nature and contains unique information while quantitative data describes
a fixed information. Last but not least, the analysis of qualitative data is done by
grouping the data into categories while quantitative data is analyzed through statistical tests
and measures. The types of data are further divided into discrete, continuous, categorical
and ordinal data, so let's take a look at each of them one by one with examples.
The data is a type of quantitative data that contains finite information which is countable
and non-negative in nature. Only a limited number of values are possible in a discrete data.
The most common example would be how many students are present in a class that only teaches
mathematics. There can only be a finite number of students that will be present in the class
and cannot be further subdivided into categories. Another example would be the number of companies
that sell healthcare products in a state or a customer purchasing information in the last quarter,
etc. And now that we are done with discrete data, let's take a look at what is continuous data.
Continuous data on the other hand is the complete opposite of the discrete data. In this type of
data any numerical infinite value can be present in the given range. For example, the daily average
temperature of the city or the revenue of a company over the last three quarters or another example
could be the measure of height for the adult males over the age of 25. And now that we are done
with continuous data, let's take a look at categorical data. The categorical data is simple to
understand. It is qualitative in nature for fall and it contains data that is classified into
categories. These categories can be binary or nominal in nature. For example, gender of a person,
educational qualifications, species of a virus mutation, etc. The significance is that there will be
a finite categories in which the data can be categorized. And now that we are done with categorical
data, let's take a look at ordinal data as well. Ordinal data despite being qualitative data
has some numerical significance. Although there are numerical categories involved, the data is still
going to be confined in a categorical state. A simple example would be the world rankings of
about players or the data that describes the shoe size of an individual in a given standard unit
to be. In a given standard unit of measurement, it will always fall in certain categories that will
also be numerical in nature. So that's all for data and different types of data guys. The significance
of learning different data types is to understand how our analysis is going to be orchestrated
since different types of data has specific properties and the statistical analysis
uncovers insights in the most efficient way. If the data presented is aligning with the statistical
method that is being used. For example, if we have to perform an AD fuller test of stationarity,
we must make sure we present the time series data for the test in order to get efficient results.
Another example would be a chi-square test of independence which only works with categorical features.
And more of this on in the upcoming sessions guys, thank you for watching and keep learning.
